title: Fn in std::ops - Rust
markdown:
# Fn in std::ops - Rust

## Trait [std](../index.html)::[ops](index.html)::[Fn](#)

1.0.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/function.rs.html#76) Â·

```
pub trait Fn<Args>: FnMut<Args>where
    Args: Tuple,{
    // Required method
    extern "rust-call" fn call(&self, args: Args) -> Self::Output;
}
```

Expand description

The version of the call operator that takes an immutable receiver.

Instances of `Fn` can be called repeatedly without mutating state.

_This trait (`Fn`) is not to be confused with [function pointers](../primitive.fn.html "primitive fn") (`fn`)._

`Fn` is implemented automatically by closures which only take immutable references to captured variables or donâ€™t capture anything at all, as well as (safe) [function pointers](../primitive.fn.html "primitive fn") (with some caveats, see their documentation for more details). Additionally, for any type `F` that implements `Fn`, `&F` implements `Fn`, too.

Since both [`FnMut`](trait.FnMut.html "trait std::ops::FnMut") and [`FnOnce`](trait.FnOnce.html "trait std::ops::FnOnce") are supertraits of `Fn`, any instance of `Fn` can be used as a parameter where a [`FnMut`](trait.FnMut.html "trait std::ops::FnMut") or [`FnOnce`](trait.FnOnce.html "trait std::ops::FnOnce") is expected.

Use `Fn` as a bound when you want to accept a parameter of function-like type and need to call it repeatedly and without mutating state (e.g., when calling it concurrently). If you do not need such strict requirements, use [`FnMut`](trait.FnMut.html "trait std::ops::FnMut") or [`FnOnce`](trait.FnOnce.html "trait std::ops::FnOnce") as bounds.

See the [chapter on closures in _The Rust Programming Language_](../../book/ch13-01-closures.html) for some more information on this topic.

Also of note is the special syntax for `Fn` traits (e.g. `Fn(usize, bool) -> usize`). Those interested in the technical details of this can refer to [the relevant section in the _Rustonomicon_](../../nomicon/hrtb.html).

## [Â§](#examples)Examples

### [Â§](#calling-a-closure)Calling a closure

```
let square = |x| x * x;
assert_eq!(square(5), 25);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++let+square+=+%7Cx%7C+x+*+x;%0A++++assert_eq!(square(5),+25);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

### [Â§](#using-a-fn-parameter)Using a `Fn` parameter

```
fn call_with_one<F>(func: F) -> usize
    where F: Fn(usize) -> usize {
    func(1)
}

let double = |x| x * 2;
assert_eq!(call_with_one(double), 2);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++fn+call_with_one%3CF%3E(func:+F)+-%3E+usize%0A++++++++where+F:+Fn(usize)+-%3E+usize+%7B%0A++++++++func(1)%0A++++%7D%0A++++%0A++++let+double+=+%7Cx%7C+x+*+2;%0A++++assert_eq!(call_with_one(double),+2);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/function.rs.html#79)

ðŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`fn_traits`Â [#29625](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/29625))

Performs the call operation.

Expand description

The version of the call operator that takes an immutable receiver.

Instances of Fn can be called repeatedly without mutating state.

This trait (Fn) is not to be confused with function pointers (fn).

Fn is implemented automatically by closures which only take immutable references to captured variables or donâ€™t capture anything at all, as well as (safe) function pointers (with some caveats, see their documentation for more details). Additionally, for any type F that implements Fn, &F implements Fn, too.

Since both FnMut and FnOnce are supertraits of Fn, any instance of Fn can be used as a parameter where a FnMut or FnOnce is expected.

Use Fn as a bound when you want to accept a parameter of function-like type and need to call it repeatedly and without mutating state (e.g., when calling it concurrently). If you do not need such strict requirements, use FnMut or FnOnce as bounds.

See the chapter on closures in The Rust Programming Language for some more information on this topic.

Also of note is the special syntax for Fn traits (e.g. Fn(usize, bool) -> usize). Those interested in the technical details of this can refer to the relevant section in the Rustonomicon.
